0.text:
Thank you very much, that’s a great guess.
So there’s been quite a lot of discussion

1.text:
recently in the bit of the History department
I hang around in most, which is around about

5.text:
Modern British Studies, about how to create
histories that are also pieces of literary

10.text:
merit in their own right, about doing great
writing in history and I have to say, this

15.text:
fills me with absolute horror and fear because
I didn’t come into history from a humanities

22.text:
background or with any particular lingering
desire to write great works of literature.

25.text:
I came into History because I knew that a
career slowly pipetting tiny doses of assay

31.text:
or sorting out drosophila flies with a camel
hair brush was not going to be a very fulfilling

36.text:
career. A lot of historians of science and
medicine are like me – refugees from careers,

42.text:
real and imagined, in the STEM subjects, in
the sciences, engineering, medicine, maths

46.text:
– and as such we know that the popular representation
of stem careers as being whiz-bang, go to

54.text:
space, cure cancer, is sort of quite lopsided.
The reality is that most people working in

60.text:
STEM careers do routine work. They are lab
technicians and they are doing the micro-pipetting

66.text:
of assays, they are handling and breeding
the lab animals, they are sitting in the basement

70.text:
at the University Hospital right now screening
tiny doses of urine for too much protein.

74.text:
They are clicking through endless screens
of mammogram shots trying to figure out whether

79.text:
someone’s got something that looks like
cancer, or possibly trying to design a computer

83.text:
to screen through all the mammogram shots
so they don’t have to.

86.text:
So the sub-disciplines of the History of Medicine
and the History and Philosophy of Science

90.text:
have got much better in the last twenty to
thirty years in recognising and recovering

95.text:
those sorts of stories and recognising the
roles of technicians, assistants, particularly

101.text:
family members, specifically often wives,
in the doing and the practising of science

106.text:
itself. In the public sphere we’re beginning
to see a fairly strong reclamation of some

112.text:
of those roles, particularly I’m thinking
about the understanding now that the original

115.text:
computers were of course people and they were
quite often women doing number crunching,

119.text:
doing the mathematics that made NASA and other
organisations work. There is however clear

125.text:
gendering of these tasks and gendering of
the way in which we talk about them. Naomi

129.text:
Oreskes who you may recognise, she works quite
a lot now on climate change, climate change

134.text:
denial and the history of climate change science,
but in some of her earlier work on the study

139.text:
of oceanography she made this very good point
about the way that we talk about drudgery

144.text:
when it comes to what women are doing and
what men are doing. With women it’s drudgery,

148.text:
it’s housework, it’s grind, it’s just
another job they have to be doing. For men

152.text:
it’s often reconstituted as being a struggle,
a struggle narrative. It’s the long dark

158.text:
days of the boring pipetting or the number
crunching, the physical comfort discomfort

162.text:
sometimes of doing the research that leads
to the great discovery and the great finding.

166.text:
Now that struggle and that plod and the fight
against boredom, the encounter with physical

171.text:
discomfort are also crucial parts to of exploration
narratives and they are sometimes deployed

177.text:
by exploration scientists to give weight and
give meaning to the work that they do and

181.text:
perhaps to offset and more effete, less macho
nerdy sort of scientist in a lab coat image

187.text:
that we might otherwise have of scientists.
These discomforts and these efforts are obviously

192.text:
gendered but they are sometimes also racialized.
Once out of the temperate zone, European scientists

197.text:
are often reliant on indigenous peoples, not
just for physical labour but also for technical

203.text:
expertise, for meteorological, geological,
medical, survival, geographical, anthropological,

209.text:
knowledge. And yet the Sherpa guide that carries
the barometer plod, plod, plod to base camp

214.text:
at Everest is a labourer, the white European
opens the box and takes the measurement with

218.text:
the instrument is the scientist, the woman
that designed the box to get it there in the

223.text:
first place is a technician back in the UK
– and so what? I’m suspecting you’re

229.text:
not the sort of audience who is massively
surprised to find that exploration can sometimes

233.text:
be quite macho or that expeditions can be
quite imperial or that science is sometimes

238.text:
gendered male, and in fact a lot of my research
into the history of extreme physiology, of

243.text:
exploration and exploration science, is asking
completely different questions about these

248.text:
sources. I’m interested in the philosophical
justification for this work. This is science

253.text:
done in an area where it could be very difficult
to fulfil the requirements for standardised

259.text:
scientific method. You don’t get to control
the environment you’re in. It’s very difficult

263.text:
to repeat an experiment if it’s been done
on the top of Everest; it’s hard to get

266.text:
there to do it in the first place. So I’m
interested in those sorts of questions, I’m

270.text:
interested in how internationalism in science
intersects with the internationalism of doing

274.text:
this sort of expeditionary work across national
boundaries with international groups, I’m

278.text:
interested in how civilian and military come
together in these spaces and I’m also interested

283.text:
in the ways in which a fairly small group
of elite white men exclude other elite white

288.text:
men from being part of their expeditions,
for a range of different reasons that could

292.text:
include things like they’re married so they
can’t come, they’re a vegetarian so they

296.text:
can’t come, or indeed that they still have
their appendix which makes them a risk in

302.text:
Antarctica. But in writing those sorts of
stories, what I’ve found is that I’m rubbing

305.text:
up the wrong way sometimes against some fairly
standardised narratives about European scientific

310.text:
exploration and challenging some standardised
explanations about why some expeditions succeed

317.text:
and others fail. They’re often centred on
exactly what sort of white man is doing this

322.text:
particular expedition, so the point of this
talk, which I am getting to, is that I need

328.text:
to reconsider one particular much loved identity
for the explorer and that’s a particularly

334.text:
British one of the gentleman amateur. But
in the deconstruction of that mythology what

338.text:
we’re going to find is that some of those
unheard voices, some of those hidden stories,

343.text:
begin to start bubbling out from the story
about the technicians, about wives, about

350.text:
Nonetheless this is still predominantly going
to be a history of men. That is something

355.text:
I’ve done pretty much throughout my work.
I remain fairly unapologetic about it as a

360.text:
focus for one pretty simple reason; the question
I pose to my undergraduate medical students

365.text:
- now the senior medics in this room need
to answer this question, you have to let everyone

370.text:
else try – sorry, this is audience participation
and I know you hate that, but it’s tough.

373.text:
What’s the name of the medical speciality
that deals with the special diseases of women?

381.text:
Gynaecology, excellent. Or gynaecology and
obstetrics. What’s the name of the medical

387.text:
specialty that deals with special diseases
of men?

396.text:
Andrology normally, but yeah, yeah. I’d
say in ten years of asking medical students

401.text:
this question, not one of them have ever managed
to get that imbalance. So the question is

406.text:
why do we have an imbalance here? Why have
we had a medical specialty on the special

411.text:
diseases of women for a good century and a
half? For men it’s andrology, more developed

415.text:
in Germany perhaps in the 1960s onwards, still
not really recognised here as a specialty.

419.text:
Why is there that disparity? The reason being
that medical specialties began to appear in

424.text:
the 19th Century at a period when the dominant
biomedical understanding was that the standard

428.text:
human body was male and that women were effectively
a deviation, an alteration, an alternative

434.text:
form of human being, to the point where the
foetus, the human foetus, was considered to

438.text:
start off as male and then become adapted
to become female through the course of its

443.text:
development. And therefore men’s bodies,
the adult male, was normal and had normal

447.text:
medicine. If you were not an adult male you
got special medicine. The old geriatrics,

451.text:
the young paediatrics, for the women gynaecology
or obs and gynae and that’s why.

457.text:
Now I’m sure many of us had similarly unbalanced
experiences when we’ve asked students to

462.text:
write essays on gender and X. There’s always
one student in the cohort who interprets that

467.text:
as meaning ‘women and X’ because after
all, only women have gender, men are normal,

471.text:
they don’t have awkward things like genders
and identities. I’ve excruciatingly experienced

476.text:
this writing sports history. Fundamentally
if you write about sports history and women

482.text:
in sports history you’re doing gender history
whether you like it or not. You’re expected

486.text:
to frame your story very much in an understanding
that has a gender pretty much at its core

491.text:
and therefore the stories you can tell – a
bit like the stories of women in science – are

495.text:
about taboo, transgression and eventually
triumph over obstacles or boundaries. On the

501.text:
flipside however it is still perfectly possibly
to write sports history that is about men

506.text:
that has no masculinity in it whatsoever and
it might not necessarily be very good sports

510.text:
history but you may well still win prizes
for it. This means that your history can be

515.text:
about something normal or it can be about
economics or politics or regional history

519.text:
or imperial history. If it has identity in
it, certainly the British case is much more

525.text:
likely to be about class identity, regional
or national identity, than it is about gender

529.text:
identity. This disparity again is not limited
to the content of the books. There is still

534.text:
an unnerving habit amongst sports historians,
and science historians, to put women in their

539.text:
books on the cover as illustrative purposes.
So I’m just going to give an example here

544.text:
– we may have to cut this out of the podcast
itself – this here is a book that has one

547.text:
chapter in it that’s women and sport, the
rest of it is about male bodies and yet it

552.text:
is illustrated with a naked non-white female
body. There is nothing about race in the book

558.text:
I took a very different approach to objectification
when I wrote my book on sports medicine, which

563.text:
was this. It was about white men and it had
a white man on the cover. I think it is therefore

569.text:
crucial that we don’t assume that it is
normal and natural for men’s bodies to climb

573.text:
mountains, do science, die nobly in the Antarctic
or anything else. We need to explain their

577.text:
presence as much as we need to explain the
absence of women’s bodies in the same spaces.

583.text:
So, if we are following the conventions of
exploration writing, this is the long trek

588.text:
in. We’ve packed our saddle bags and our
yaks, filled up our snow cats or whatever

593.text:
it is with all the intellectual baggage that
we need. This is why I don’t want to write

598.text:
literary histories, this is why it’s terrifying
to me. This is a terrible metaphor but we’ve

601.text:
packed all this stuff in, we’ve done the
long trek in and we are ready for the story

606.text:
itself. Most of that story is going to be
based around here, which is Everest, given

611.text:
its Western name 1856 after the grand surveyor
of India, George Everest. We’re going to

616.text:
take some detours to Antarctica and there
is a logic to taking those two sites together

622.text:
which is simply that there’s a pretty vast
exchange of personnel and technology between

627.text:
the two sites, certainly in the first half
of the 20th Century, the roll-call of expedition

631.text:
members certainly among the Europeans throw
up familiar name after familiar name. There’s

637.text:
a great deal of technical and scientific exchange
between the two locations, not just in terms

641.text:
of equipment but also things like logistics,
how you plan an expedition and so on. While

647.text:
obviously these environments vary significantly
there are some very core shared physiological

653.text:
and survival problems about altitude, about
cold, about doing hard work in isolated places.

659.text:
OK, so the image I’m going to start off
with is the one that I hope is relatively

665.text:
familiar to you, which is the heroic age British
explorer. This is the promotional image I

670.text:
picked for the talk; it’s Edward Wilson,
also known as Bill Wilson. This is obviously

675.text:
a promotional, a romanticised promotional
image often used in biographies of him. I

680.text:
believe this is actually, because of the dogs’
centrality in this, I think this is probably

687.text:
the Discovery Expedition which was 1901-1904,
but the plug at the bottom which you won’t

692.text:
be able to read reminds us that he died outward
Scott at the South Pole in 1912. Photographs

700.text:
of expeditions are also promotional images.
It’s easier to see it perhaps in a painting

705.text:
but we need to remember that it’s also true
for the photographs that we begin to see in

708.text:
the 20th Century. Pre-digital photography,
it’s bulky, it’s expensive, it has to

714.text:
also be very carefully designed so that it
actually works in the environmental challenges

718.text:
of places like Antarctica or Everest. So while
you increasingly get what you could consider

723.text:
to be more casual snapshots, many expensive
and rare photographs effectively on these

729.text:
expeditions are taken for some specific purpose,
often a promotional purpose. They might be

736.text:
scientific or geographical images of routes
and avenues and ways up a mountain, or places

743.text:
in Antarctica, but they’re often also taken
with half an eye to the production of a nice,

748.text:
glossy, exploration book at the end of it,
the advance for which has probably been at

752.text:
least part of the funding for the expedition
itself. Hence we end up with sort of images

756.text:
like these, all from the Royal Geographical
Society. Again, if they’re not familiar

760.text:
in their specificness [sic], they are familiar
in their sort of generality. You’ve seen

764.text:
photographs like this before, this is probably
what you imagine when you think of early 20th

769.text:
Century British explorers. We recognise this
romanticised image of the tweed-clad gentlemanly

774.text:
amateur British climber, the sort of person
who goes up a mountain just because it’s

778.text:
there, who thinks using oxygen to do it is
cheating, who insists on having a tea party

783.text: at base camp, that sort of thing.

786.text:
So these are the people who are casting their
eyes over Everest as a destination, end of

791.text:
the 19th, beginning of the 20th Century, largely
foiled by refusals for permits from local

796.text:
governments in Nepal and in Tibet. The British
relationship with Tibet begins to improve

802.text:
around about World War I. This is when Tibet
is gaining its independence. 1913 is when

809.text:
the news breaks largely in Britain that Scott
and his team have died on their attempt to

813.text:
come back from the South Pole, which means
that Brits have failed to be the first to

818.text:
the North Pole, they failed spectacularly
to be first to the South Pole and you begin

822.text:
to see people referring to Everest as ‘the
third pole’, the idea that this is a last

826.text:
chance exploratory first for a fading imperial
nation. Consequently, a series of expeditions

833.text:
take place in the 1920s, 30s and 50s; they’re
funded largely by the Alpine Club, the Royal

839.text:
Geographical Society, organisations like that.
Three expeditions in the 20s, 21, 22, 24 – the

845.text:
final push which leads to the death of George
Mallory and Sandy Irving – and because of

850.text:
those fatalities, also the deaths of Sherpa
on a previous expedition caused largely by

855.text:
Mallory and what we’d consider to be transgressive
activities which was collecting geological

861.text:
specimens which had not been given permission.
The Dalai Lama closes the Tibetan border to

867.text:
the British and it’s not reopened again
until the 30s when there’s another flush

871.text:
of expeditions – 33, 36, 38 and a reconnaissance
in 35.

876.text:
Post-war there’s not a huge sense of urgency
to get back up the mountain again but plans

881.text:
do start to be made for another attempt and
it’s actually a medical man, a surgeon called

886.text:
Michael Ward who really pushes the process
on by going over old aerial photographs and

891.text:
maps and coming up with a new route up Everest
from the Nepalese side as opposed to the Tibetan

897.text:
side. China has annexed Tibet which means
the British are now having to get through

900.text:
Nepal. This is the focus of the reconnaissance
in 1951, all going very well, and then to

905.text:
the British horror the Nepalese government
grant the Swiss permission to go up Everest

909.text:
not once, but twice, in 1952, pre and post-monsoon.
And this basically signals the end of that

915.text:
privileged unique access to Everest that the
British had had before. It’s pretty clear

920.text:
that there’s a long queue of other nations
who want to get up there and if the British

923.text:
are going to successfully be able to do it,
they’ve got to do it now or never. So there’s

927.text:
a very concerted effort into scientific testing
of oxygen and other equipment in 52 and then

932.text:
eventually the successful 1953 expedition
when two men do reach the summit, although

938.text: of course neither of them are British.

940.text:
So these are our gentlemen amateurs. They
are sponsored by the Alpine Club, they are

944.text:
sponsored by the Foreign Office, they are
vetted and chosen from the elite of the climbing

948.text:
world. They are pretty frequently Oxbridge
graduates. Some of them have never really

954.text:
been to altitude prior to going to Everest;
they’ve climbed in Snowdonia, done a bit

957.text:
of Alpine climbing, but that’s pretty much
it. They are climbing in tweedy suits, they

960.text:
are climbing in hobnail boots, they are clearly
having tea and biscuits. 1933, the rations

967.text:
for the trek to Base Camp included half a
dozen kinds of breakfast food, bacon, ham,

973.text:
beef, mutton, chicken, lobster, crab, salmon,
herrings, cod roes, asparagus, caviar, foie

977.text:
gras, smoked salmon, sausages, many kinds
of cheese, a dozen varieties of biscuit, jam,

982.text:
marmalade, honey, chocolate, sweets, toffee,
tinned peas, beans and spaghetti. The expeditions

986.text:
of the 50s tended to talk about themselves
to be much more scientific and rational than

990.text:
these of the 30s but they too seriously considered
taking foie gras with them, not just to luxurious

997.text:
Base Camp but actually in the emergency rations
for the summit dash itself. And inevitably

1003.text:
that story in the long quote of foods does
raise a bit of a smile. In fact the 53 expedition

1007.text:
didn’t take foie gras in the end; the Swiss
did though on both their expeditions in 52,

1012.text:
so this is clearly not just a national issue.
I’m not going to ask you to guess why you

1017.text:
might want to take foie gras. I’m going
to quote you from a letter written by a Doctor

1021.text:
at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical
Medicine. This is in response to a guy called

1026.text:
Lewis Griffith Creswell Evans Pugh, the gloriously
name ‘Griff Pugh’, who is investigating

1031.text:
the ration pack during a lot of physiological
work for the 53 expedition. He’s particularly

1036.text:
interested in blood and respiration. It’s
clear that there are significant changes to

1040.text:
the blood when you go to altitude. One significant
change is an increase in the amount of haemoglobin

1045.text:
you have. So he’s writing to a doctor to
ask about foods that produce haemoglobin and

1051.text:
Dr Grant replies, “the foods that are supposed
to be of the most value when haemoglobin has

1055.text:
to be made are 1) liver, kidney and gizzard,
2) egg, heart and 3) apricots, peaches, prunes

1061.text:
and apples. It looks as though you ought to
take pate de foie gras and caviar in the basic

1066.text:
diet, maybe more cheaply liver sausage and
smoked cod roe”. There’s nothing amateur,

1071.text:
there’s nothing even particularly luxurious
about taking foie gras up a mountain, it’s

1075.text:
an energy and nutritionally dense food, it’s
conveniently available in robust packaging

1080.text:
which is resistant to spoilage and crucially
too it’s a familiar, digestible, palatable

1085.text:
and pleasant food for the sorts of men who
are in fact going to do the climbing. The

1089.text:
long provision list for the 1930s, which was
also seen in the 20s expeditions and to a

1094.text:
similar extent in the 50s, has a completely
scientific rationale too. For one thing it’s

1099.text:
making the most of the miracle of safe tinned
foods, but for another we know it as a fact

1103.text:
that altitude changes your sense of taste.
If you’ve ever been in an aeroplane you’ve

1108.text:
experienced that to a limited amount. One
of the perpetual problems of early high altitude

1113.text:
mountaineering is that mountaineers just don’t
eat enough. They seem to lose their appetite,

1117.text:
they lose weight even when there’s plenty
of food available. It’s one of the things

1121.text:
that makes a real difference between them
and Antarctic explorers because the Antarctic

1125.text:
explorers generally seem to have a pretty
robust appetite, you know, they will eat blubber

1129.text:
candles if the need pushes them to it. Mountaineers
however seem to be tempted to eat enough.

1136.text:
They need strong, bold, familiar, varied flavours
in order to keep up an appetite. And in particular

1142.text:
the trekking at this point could take an extremely
long time. You cannot afford for our mountaineers

1146.text:
to become pre-bored of the food that they’re
going to eat before they’ve even managed

1150.text:
to make it to the serious part of the mountain
itself. At least one significant British explorer

1157.text:
– again, somebody who pioneered oxygen therapy,
the use of oxygen on the mountain – had

1162.text:
died of dysentery on the way out during one
of the 1920s expeditions, so relying on local

1166.text:
food and local water was not a particularly
popular option and unlike polar expeditions

1171.text:
you have far fewer restrictions on the sheer
amount of stuff you can take with you, at

1175.text:
least to Base Camp. So it’s possible to
take luxurious ranges of stuff to make sure

1180.text:
your mountaineers eat enough to get up the
mountain in the first place.

1184.text:
I’m going to quote from an article by Paul
Gilchrist who’s published quite widely on

1190.text:
masculinity in mountaineering. “The first
seven expeditions to the mountain between

1195.text:
21 and 38 was symbolically and culturally
British affairs. The climbing parties were

1199.text:
largely composed of men of the upper middle
classes, which is true, a veritable gentlemen’s

1204.text:
club, fitted out with the niceties of such
an institution”. In 1924 for instance, the

1209.text:
climbers softened the hardship to the uncompromising
high altitude environment by taking with them

1214.text:
60 tins of quail and foie gras, vintage Montebello
champagne, together with bow ties, umbrellas,

1219.text:
bowler hats, which completed their image as
Englishmen abroad. Now I should say, I’ve

1225.text:
not found any references to bowler hats or
bow ties in any of the shipping manifests

1229.text:
for the 20s and 30s expeditions. It doesn’t
mean that they didn’t take them. The climbers

1233.text:
themselves took some of their own stuff, some
of their own clothes. They certainly had the

1237.text:
gear to pose for traditional Englishmen photographs
which were indeed taken, but I think it’s

1242.text:
also worth pointing out that they were all
expected to attend formal events in Kathmandu

1246.text:
and elsewhere, so they also had to take formal
dress with them for those purposes. Champagne,

1252.text:
just for reference at this point, is still
being used by marathon runners and endurance

1255.text:
runners as a tonic. It was regarded as a form
of medical treatment in the same way that

1259.text:
you might also take brandy. It’s not hugely
unusual to have it with you. The expeditions

1264.text:
definitely took umbrellas. Even umbrellas
however turn out to be not quite what they

1268.text:
seem, or rather turn out to be exactly what
they seem. The 53 expedition took umbrellas

1272.text:
and a photograph of some of the explorers
with them led someone to write to the Royal

1277.text:
Geographical Society to say ‘why on earth
did you all take typical black umbrellas out

1281.text:
with you to climb mount Everest?’ and the
answer was ‘we carried umbrellas on the

1285.text:
march in from Kathmandu instead of sun shades
and on the march out to keep the rain off.

1291.text:
The monsoon was beginning, it is as pleasant
to be dry in Nepal as it is in England’.

1295.text: So sometimes an umbrella is just an umbrella.

1297.text:
There is no doubt that these were men who
had to keep up a certain appearance. They

1303.text:
had to maintain a certain personal identity,
but we mustn’t let our assumptions about

1307.text:
what is and isn’t a suitable exploration
food about the symbolism of foie gras, yet

1312.text:
in the way of our understanding of this seriousness
and the professionalism of these attempts

1317.text:
to climb the very high mountains. What we
see much less frequently alongside the comedy

1323.text:
lists of unlikely foods is all of the other
stuff they took with them. The cutting edge

1328.text:
radio equipment, the specially designed field
medical kits from Burrows, Welcome and Co,

1334.text:
which had been field tested to survive being
dropped of a yak into a crevasse and things

1337.text:
like that. The shoes are specifically tailored
to their feet and this is actually Ed Hillary’s

1343.text:
foot, slightly over the standard size that
the Royal Geographical Society was expecting

1348.text:
for making boots. There is reams and reams
and weeks and weeks of negotiation by letter

1355.text:
about exactly how the soles of these boots

1359.text:
meticulous attention to detail for these sorts
of pieces of equipment. The gabardine waterproofs

1366.text:
that they’re wearing are the latest from
Burberry. Shackleton’s boots and Shackleton’s

1370.text:
sledging outfits as they were known, this
is an adventure clothing material that has

1375.text:
been meticulously tested. When George Mallory’s
body was rediscovered in 1999, some samples

1380.text:
of his clothes were taken and sent back to
the UK and two or three local material science

1385.text:
labs, one in Leeds, tested the, or recreated
the clothing he was wearing, tested it and

1391.text:
compared it to the weather on Everest in 1924
and declared that he was fully protected against

1397.text:
the environment. The 20s clothing was perfectly
adequate for getting to the summit of Everest

1401.text: in terms of keeping you warm and dry.

1404.text:
Most of these men at some point had their
blood taken, they’ve had their lung capacity

1409.text:
measured for the purpose of improving the
physiological support that could be given

1413.text:
to them in terms of the medical box but also

1419.text:
So however committed these men were to amateur
ideals or to their gentlemanly behaviours

1425.text:
and identity, not one single climber went
to Everest wearing their second best boots.

1430.text:
Every team meant to succeed. Every team leveraged
every advantage they had – social, financial,

1437.text:
physical, scientific - everything they had
at their disposal to get this right. With

1443.text:
one exception. These are of course the official

1448.text:
one, 1933-4, that consists of one man called
Morris Wilson and the Sherpa that he manages

1453.text:
to hire while he’s out there. I’m not
going to give you the details of his story,

1456.text:
it’s a bit complicated because he doesn’t
have permission to go out to Everest, he’s

1460.text:
having to kind of get out there secretly.
I mean not that secret, he has an aeroplane

1465.text:
that he flies, but it’s things like he lands
at one airport and they say ‘no, you’ve

1467.text:
got no permission. You can only refuel if
you promise to go home’ and he goes ‘cross

1470.text:
my heart, I promise to go home’ and they
refuel him and he flies off to wherever he

1474.text:
wants to go. When he finally gets closer to

monk, realising then that he can’t speak

1481.text:
to be deaf and dumb anytime anyone talks to
him; that sort of story.

1486.text:
Wilson has no ice climbing experience. He
believed that world peace could be brought

1491.text:
about by fasting and religious devotion. It
seems that his plan was to climb Everest possibly

1497.text:
powered by the inner strength that was brought
to him by not eating. He dies, rather obviously,

1503.text:
in the attempt and his body and diary are
discovered during the official 1935 expedition.

1507.text:
The reason I mean him really is that part
of his naivety may have been encouraged by

1514.text:
the way in which the 1920s expedition was
reported. Much more of jolly dare and do by

1520.text:
brave men than it was a high-tech, deeply
prepared expert expedition. The moral of this

1527.text:
story obviously is that false news costs lives.
Disdaining experts costs lives. This is not

1534.text:
to say that there’s no argument over the
tech. Because the tech was so important, there

1539.text:
were huge debates. People with experience
faced off against those who were doing the

1543.text:
work, mostly in the lab or in theory. People
with alpine experience faced off against those

1547.text:
with arctic experience, like which of those
is more relevant if you’re going up Everest?

1551.text:
And one of the really big areas of debate
was over the use of supplemental oxygen. OK,

1555.text:
so a tiny bit of science. So Everest is very
high up, there is less physical atmosphere

1562.text:
above you at the summit of Everest than there
is if you’re at sea level. So if you stand

1564.text:
on top of a mountain there’s less atmosphere
pushing down on you. Now when you put pressure

1570.text:
on a gas, like atmospheric oxygen, you compress
it and when you relieve that pressure you

1575.text:
release it and it expands. So as you go up
the mountain the air becomes less and less

1580.text:
dense and that basically means because there’s
less atmospheric pressure, every breath you

1585.text:
take at altitude, simply put, it has fewer
oxygen molecules in it. By the 1920s a fairly

1592.text:
hard-fought scientific battle has led to the
general consensus that altitude sickness and

1596.text:
the fatigue you experience while climbing
to high altitude is due to specifically the

1601.text:
lack of oxygen and the obvious solution therefore
is take some of your own oxygen with you to

1605.text:
supplement and to prepare for this problem.
That turns out to be a hugely challenging

1611.text:
technical problem. It really isn’t solved
super-effectively until the 1950s. It’s

1615.text:
one of the major reasons for the failures
of the earlier expeditions. Oxygen systems

1623.text:
can be very heavy so they have to work really
effectively because not only do they have

1626.text:
to compensate for the altitude but they also
have to compensate for all the extra work

1630.text:
you’re having to do carrying the system
itself. They have a tendency to freeze up,

1636.text:
the valves not to work, the masks to be uncomfortable,
the flow rate of the oxygen not to be enough.

1639.text:
They’re a really challenging technical feat
and this is really the breakthrough that Griff

1644.text:
Pugh and others managed to do in the 50s that
made 53 such a success, a functional high

1648.text:
altitude oxygen system. But what Griff Pugh
and also Mike Ward said about the earlier

1657.text:
expeditions was one that set the tone I think
for historians writing subsequently. When

1661.text:
they managed to succeed in 53, what they said
retrospectively about the previous oxygen

1667.text:
systems in the 20s and 30s was that the futile
controversy over the ethics of using oxygen,

1672.text:
the failure to accept the findings of pioneers
and its application, handicapped for 30 years

1677.text:
the introduction of a method that promises
to revolutionise high altitude mountaineering.

1682.text:
That’s debatably not true but it sets the
tone for the writing that came afterwards.

1687.text:
The narrative is set that it’s ethics, it’s
gentlemanly sporting attitudes that resist

1692.text:
oxygen because it’s cheating and this amateur
gentlemanly rejection of science and technology

1697.text:
is what retards British success and fails
to get up the mountain.

1702.text:
To counter that of the fairly obvious photographs
of Mallory and Irving in 1924 on Everest,

1707.text:
wearing the gas canisters, they were persuaded
finally actually worked, having actually made

1713.text:
some really important on-site adjustments
to them, I think particularly to make the

1717.text:
valves more functional when you’re wearing
gloves easier to turn. Both of these men who

1721.text:
are darlings of the amateur climbing world,
both of them climbed to their deaths wearing

1725.text:
these pieces of equipment and this technical
assistance. There is a debate about oxygen

1730.text:
but by and large it doesn’t pit gentlemanly
amateurs against scientific rationalists.

1735.text:
What it generally pits is men of experience
against armchair mathematicians. I’m not

1741.text:
going to go too much into the detail of this;
it is pretty fantastically nerdy stuff about

1746.text:
standard atmospheres and how barometric chambers
work and things like this. I find it fascinating

1751.text:
but it does tend to make some audiences gloss
over slightly. So I’m just going to pre-warn

1756.text:
you that the deadly quote you need to look
out for is this one about rotters. It comes

1760.text:
from AR Hinks, a Cambridge astronomer, member
of the Royal Geographical Society. He’s

1764.text:
writing to the Alpine Club in 1922 – you
will sometimes see this used as titles of

1770.text:
articles and book chapters and things like
this. If you see it presented without context,

1776.text:
be really wary of the content that follows.
It’s usually mobilised to suggest basically

1781.text:
that people using oxygen on Everest are rotters,
they’re cheats, this is the British amateur

1786.text:
attitude, this is a terrible thing that made
everything go wrong. This is not what’s

1790.text:
happening at all. Firstly you need to be aware
that 7,600 metres is significantly below the

1797.text:
summit of Everest. This is the height to which
human beings had quite easily got before and

1801.text:
managed to climb. We all know that human beings
can adapt and survive at this altitude. And

1807.text:
secondly, what this is is a critique of an
armchair – as they call it – scientist

1810.text:
George Dreyer. Dreyer’s crunched the numbers,
effectively got something wrong and has come

1816.text:
up with this idea that about 7,600 metres
is the limit for human survival and that you

1820.text:
must use oxygen above this. We know this not
to be true. The reason Dreyer is saying this

1825.text:
is largely because he works with aeroplanes
and barometric chambers and it’s not allowing

1830.text:
for human acclimatisation, which is what happens
if you climb very slowly up a mountain like

1834.text:
Everest. So basically lab experience doesn’t
always map onto real world experience. That’s

1839.text:
the debate that’s been happening here. It’s
nothing to do with sportsmanship.

1843.text:
There is a preference for climbing the mountain
without oxygen if it’s physically possible.

1846.text:
There’s definitely a sense that if you can
do it without oxygen that should be the goal.

1850.text:
A lot of the early expeditions had two summit
attempts – one without oxygen and one with

1855.text:
oxygen. The reason there is that, the logic
is that if you do it with oxygen and it’s

1860.text:
possible without, all that will happen is
that some other country will come along afterwards

1863.text:
and then do it without oxygen. We want the
full stop, we want to climb Everest all the

1867.text:
possible ways it’s possible to climb Everest
and this is going to be a British success

1870.text:
and no-one else is going to take it from us.
That’s generally how the teams are setting

1873.text:
themselves up. There is quite a lot of chaffing
in the records about having to do boring things

1879.text:
like try on masks and do oxygen drills and
all sorts of things like this. A lot of the

1884.text:
mountaineers rightly object when the equipment
doesn’t work, they complain about the stuff

1888.text:
that doesn’t function, they won’t use
it if they think it’s dangerous to them,

1891.text:
if it slows them down or if it freezes up,
if it can’t be used, but these are all practical

1895.text:
objections. These are not ideological objections
to oxygen itself. The teams found all sorts

1901.text:
of other artificial assistance perfectly acceptable.
Rather a lot’s been made recently of the

1907.text:
use of amphetamines, particularly false march
tablets by Scotts teams and others in Antarctica.

1912.text:
I think you should balance that with the fact
that pretty much every European attempt at

1916.text:
the high Himalaya has been kitted out with
a variety of interesting stimulants, mostly

1920.text:
cocaine and amphetamines. In the archives
of the 1920s expeditions there’s actually

1926.text:
a note saying that Mallory himself has written
to the expedition leader to say that young

1930.text:
Haldane – that’s JBS Haldane for those
that know their chemists – young Haldane

1934.text:
professes to be able to recommend a stimulant
similar to caffeine and cola, but better in

1939.text:
oculus, I’ll get in touch with him about
it.

1942.text:
What is happening here is the different stories
about exploration, about the personal qualities

1947.text:
that makes someone a great explorer or scientist,
get overlaid onto one another. The self-representation

1953.text:
of the 20s and 30s probably did emphasise
the daring do at the expense of the dull plod,

1958.text:
plod, plod, but essential scientific work.
The participants are largely the elite young

1963.text:
men of empire and certainly their deaths have
to be framed in such a way that they don’t

1968.text:
ring hollow or they don’t ring pointless
but are seen as noble and fearless and with

1973.text:
purpose. We then have the 1950s expeditions
and how they talk about the failed expeditions

1978.text:
of the 20s and 30s and these do characterise
them as being of the past. Those 20s and 30s

1983.text:
people, they were far closer to the Victorians
than we, the modern scientific men of the

1988.text:
50s are now. We are the smart modern men of
the new Century. The timing of Everest obviously

1993.text:
coincides with the start of a new Elizabethan
era in the UK. There’s been a significant

2000.text:
increase in governments funding scientific
projects, big science like the Atom project

2005.text:
but also in the UK projects like the NHS.
We are in the decade for the 50s expeditions

2011.text:
where C.P. Snow will eventually deliver his
infamous lecture on the two cultures – a

2015.text:
critique of the lack of science and the persistence
of liberal values and also the study of the

2021.text:
humanities in the corridors of power amongst
civil servants and others.

2026.text:
So here perhaps is an opportunity for the
scientific go-getters of the 50s to take the

2031.text:
robust masculinity of a commonwealth citizen
who finally gets up Everest and temper it

2035.text:
with British military logistics that plan
the expedition and with high tech scientific

2040.text:
advice that finally has succeeded where the
old generations had failed. Over that interpretation

2047.text:
we then have what the historians have written,
the stories they’ve chosen to tell about

2050.text:
these events. The tendency of reinventing
exploration stories is probably more obvious

2058.text:
in the dash to the Pole than it is for Everest.
I suspect the reason for that is that is that

2063.text:
there’s a much more obvious national rivalry
going on in Antarctica. Apart from the Swiss,

2067.text:
Everest is mostly a British affair until it’s
successfully climbed. But with the South Pole,

2072.text:
I mean you could pick your own interpretation
and eat it, frankly. I mean we have Scott

2077.text:
failed because he was an amateur gentleman
and he prioritised the graft and the physicality

2083.text:
of man hauling, rather being like Amundsen
who cheated and relied on a technical advantage,

2088.text:
ie dog sleds. We can have Scott failing because
he didn’t single-mindedly just go for the

2093.text:
sporting goal but he also did science along
the way, collecting rocks and penguin eggs

2097.text:
– that’s either a good thing or a terrible
thing and an example again of why British

2102.text:
male elite gentlemanly amateurism was a terrible
thing for British progress. We can have Scott

2109.text:
failing because as a true Brit he loves dogs
and he couldn’t possibly bring himself to

2114.text:
a plan that involved eating them on the way
back, unlike again the terrible foreigner

2117.text:
who managed to get to the South Pole first
etc, etc, etc, etc. There are plenty of other

2122.text:
explanations. As is so often the case, the
explanations tell you a lot more perhaps about

2128.text:
the historians than they do about Scott himself.
The reclamation of Scott’s scientific work

2133.text:
as part of that explanation came about around
about the 1980s which had a boost in the 90s

2139.text:
and again now, but with Everest the reclamation
of the scientific work really doesn’t happen

2144.text:
until 2013 which is when Griff Pughs daughter,
Harriet, publishes this meticulously researched

2152.text:
biography of her dad’s work. Not just his
Everest work but focusing on that. The lack

2157.text:
of Everest as a scientific triumph narrative
is a little bit puzzling given that the men

2163.text:
of the 50s were quite keen to frame it that
way, but the amateur tweedy climber eating

2169.text:
foie gras is still such a tempting target
for popular history and it’s very easy as

2174.text:
I pointed out to miss the science that’s
going on because of our prejudices about what

2178.text:
is scientific nutrition, what is a rational
way of climbing a mountain.

2182.text:
The other reason it took us a long time to
get the scientific interpretation of 53 is

2188.text:
much more individual and specific and it’s
to do with the down-playing of Griff Pugh’s

2193.text:
role. He seems to have been one of those people
who you either got on with or you massively

2197.text:
didn’t get on with. There were certainly
a lot of people who deeply disliked and resented

2201.text:
him. He goes on to collaborate with Hillary
two more times in a trans-Antarctic commonwealth

2207.text:
crossing at the end of the 50s during the
IGY and then on the Silver Hut Expedition

2211.text:
in 1960-61, which is a seminal altitude physiology
field study for the 20th Century. So many

2217.text:
of the papers we currently see relate back
to the work done in this hut. The relationship

2222.text:
between the two men is clearly always difficult.
Hillary perhaps not so keen on always giving

2227.text:
the credit in expeditions, particularly for
things like the scientific support which he

2232.text:
received, the use of oxygen for climbing,
and during Silver Hut there is a disastrous

2238.text:
summit attempt on [Maccalu] where mismanagement
and misjudgement result in a failed evacuation

2246.text:
off the mountain and one climber called Peter
Mulgrew ends up having both his legs amputated

2250.text:
just below the knee. It’s pretty clear from
the archive materials relating to all three

2255.text:
of these expeditions, but particularly the
last one, Silver Hut, that the popular accounts

2260.text:
written by Hillary contain - what shall we
charitably call them? – alternative facts.

2267.text:
Griff Pugh never wrote his side of the story
in a popular venue and I suspect it’s the

2271.text:
lop-sidedness, the disparity of these two
accounts or the absence of one account and

2276.text:
the presence of another account, that had
a very strong line that they wanted to tell

2279.text:
which included disparaging the scientific
work that was being done and that is why it’s

2284.text:
taken us a long time to reclaim Everest as
a scientific achievement.

2288.text:
I’m making heavy weather of this because
sometimes it is about social attitudes. Sometimes

2294.text:
these representations are about what will
sell newspaper stories, what will persuade

2298.text:
funders, but sometimes it is about individuals,
it is about a single strong-willed influence

2303.text:
individual who is able to push and maintain
a certain interpretation, particularly in

2308.text:
this case one that’s not necessarily a gentlemanly
amateur but one which is a very macho physically

2314.text:
embodied and understood exploration of identity.
I also make heavy weather of this a bit because

2320.text:
I want an excuse to bring in Peter Mulgrew
because I think he’s a neat Segway into

2325.text:
thinking more about the stories that we’re
not telling about this exploration and in

2331.text:
So Peter Mulgrew was a New Zealand climber.
He went on the trans-Antarctic trip across

2339.text:
Antarctica with Hillary, often as a radio
operator as he’s pictured here, and then

2345.text:
he becomes a climber in the Silver Hut Expedition
which is where not only does he suffer a serious

2349.text:
amputation but also for a while becomes addicted
to painkillers. So these are men whose lives

2355.text:
are filled with disaster and distress. For
example, 1975 Hillary loses his first wife

2362.text:
and daughter in a light aeroplane crash as
they fly out to the Himalaya to meet him.

2368.text:
A couple of years later, 1979, he offers Mulgrew
post-amputation an opportunity to earn some

2374.text:
money. Hillary’s been asked to go on a tour
flight around Antarctica with fee paying people,

2379.text:
passengers, so he can give like a running
commentary to them as they fly over various

2382.text:
important sites. He has a diary clash and
so he asked Mulgrew to take his place instead.

2387.text:
Air New Zealand Flight 901 crashes into an
Antarctic mountain on the 28th November 1979

2392.text:
and it leaves no survivors; one of the most
serious disasters in Air New Zealand’s history.

2397.text:
Ten years after that Edmund Hillary marries
Mulgrew’s widow.

2404.text:
So some of these stories are really hard to
resist. You want to include them and I know

2408.text:
why historians want to put them in their books
and their articles but even within these stories

2412.text:
are myths. They are stereotypes that explorers
themselves use and particularly they are stereotypes

2419.text:
that represent women and families as hostages
to fortune, as risks, as distractions, as

2425.text:
stuff you don’t really want – baggage
you don’t really want to be taking with

2428.text:
you. Large scale, particularly state-sponsored
expeditions whether they’re scientifically

2433.text:
focused or not, to the high Himalaya and to
Antarctica from Europe and North America are

2438.text:
almost exclusively male affairs, right the
way through to the very dying decades of the

2442.text:
20th Century and this is both deliberate and
accidental. To climb Everest you need the

2449.text:
permissions, you need the visa, you need the
experience, you need the support of the Foreign

2452.text:
Office, you need the money, valuable and very
hard to come by if you’re a man, that’s

2455.text:
one of the reasons why it remains a venue
mostly for a certain social class of man.

2461.text:
If you’re a woman it is pretty much impossible.
That is if you’re a European or a North

2468.text:
American woman. Russian and China managed
to get access to the mountain shortly after

2473.text:
the Second World War and they were pretty
quick at getting women into pretty much the

2480.text:
first exploration parties on the mountain
itself. So this is a European and North American

2484.text:
women’s problem, not necessarily a Russian
or a Chinese woman’s problem.

2488.text:
In Antarctica the answer for women was pretty
much a policy. US congress only lifted in

2495.text:
1969 its official ban on women in Antarctica.
American Naval support was so important to

2502.text:
people who wanted to get out there and also
to stay in the bases there that it pretty

2505.text:
much effectively worked as a bar for women
from any country. There are some exceptions.

2511.text:
Certainly much earlier in the time period
there are some accounts of the wives and family

2515.text:
members of whalers who perhaps had set foot
on the continent itself and there are a couple

2520.text:
of Soviet Union women who managed I think
in the 40s to make it quite close in a ship

2525.text:
as they were doing oceanography. There are
two Pan-Am air stewardesses who got on a flight

2531.text:
to Antarctica and they get off and for about
an hour they walk around on the continent;

2534.text:
they’re pretty much the first women to set
foot there as far as we know. And then extraordinarily

2540.text:
an American geologist, Dawn Rodley, managed
to get permission to go on an expedition as

2546.text:
part of the IGY. When I say ‘permission’,
I mean she had to get permission from all

2551.text:
the male members of the expeditionary team
and then she had to get permission from all

2555.text:
of their wives before she was going to be
allowed to go. And even then the US Navy refused

2560.text:
to transport her, so in the end she missed
out on this opportunity. And the permission

2564.text:
from the wives is clearly the insight into
the issue that is happening here. Women are

2568.text:
consistently represented as disruptive elements.
The Brits keep women out of Antarctica in

2575.text:
a more semi-informal way. Vivian Fuchs, the
explorer scientist who ran the British Antarctic

2581.text:
Survey for an extended period of time was
also one of the leaders on the trans-Antarctic

2584.text:
commonwealth expedition with Hillary, he specifically
said that women ‘disrupted the harmony and

2594.text:
scientific productivity of Antarctic bases’
and British women didn’t get out to Antarctica

2599.text:
until 1983 and even then there was no British
women doing the winter season in Antarctica

2605.text:
until extraordinarily 1996. In case you don’t
recognise it, that’s an unbearded Vivian

2611.text:
Fuchs showing his route across to a very young
David Attenborough.

2615.text:
So the feared disruption of women in these
spaces is unquestionably sexual. There’s

2620.text:
a lot of discrimination about this, you know,
they will say things like ‘we don’t have

2624.text:
enough toilets for the women’ or in one
case ‘there’s no hairdresser in Antarctica,

2630.text:
the women won’t be happy here’. But it’s
pretty clear that what they really fear is

2632.text:
that the homosocial atmosphere of these spaces,
of exploration and research bases, is going

2637.text:
to be disrupted by sexual tension. These are
after all intensely homo-socialised men, at

2642.text:
least until the 1960s and at least for the
British case. They’re going from single

2647.text:
sex private schools to mostly male only universities,
certainly male only Oxbridge colleges. They’re

2653.text:
often working in male only military government
or scientific positions. These are not men

2658.text:
who’ve ever really had to have women as
co-workers before. It’s perhaps no surprise

2662.text:
to find that they are frightened and unequal
to the challenge of doing so in extraordinary

2668.text:
tense situations. And yet, they are also men
who form lasting, deep and in some cases,

2679.text:
clearly emotionally encloses, romantic if
not necessarily sexual relationships with

2684.text:
each other. And ensuring group harmony is
an obsession with the early 20th Century expeditions.

2692.text:
They are long, they are isolated, very small
arguments can have extraordinarily deadly

2697.text:
consequences and you can see that time and
time again in the records. And for those that

2702.text:
have left archives, I’ve found intense and
personal discussion about whether this man

2707.text:
or that man should be the tenth member of
your exploration party and the reasons for

2711.text:
rejection can genuinely be things like ‘I
really didn’t like his sense of humour on

2715.text:
the last expedition’, or ‘he hums a lot
and it drives me crazy’. This is the sort

2720.text:
of thing that can really matter if you’re
stuck with someone through an Antarctic winter.
